node.title: Fraser-McGurk takes a blinder as Renegades win BBL thriller over Strikers
node.description: The BBL is only three games old, but Jake Fraser-McGurk may already have the catch of the summer — the teenager leapt high at Docklands to take an absolute screamer, to dismiss Adelaide's Jake Weatherald in the Melbourne Renegades' two-run win.

node.title: John Lennon's murder, the Cold War and the Red Bikini Girl
node.description: John Lennon was gunned down at his New York apartment 41 years ago. Beatles fans remember what they were doing on that day, including reporter Jason Dasey, who was chasing a Soviet defector on Sydney Harbour at the height of the Cold War.

node.title: Search data shows Australia is a nation of sport lovers, but our favourite is foreign
node.description: Google has released its year in search list for 2021, and sports took out seven of the top 10 spots in Australia overall.

node.title: We fact checked Scott Morrison on Australia's emissions compared to the G20. Here's what we found
node.description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says Australia's emissions have come down 20 per cent, a record he says is beaten by only four other countries in the G20. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

node.title: New Zealand to host Sail GP for four years
node.description: New Zealand is back on the calendar for the Sail GP series after a four-year deal was confirmed for events on Aotearoa waters.

node.title: Police union wants iwi to prove value of Northland border checkpoints
node.description: It's feared checkpoints in Northland could suck up valuable police resources this summer, while failing to stop unvaccinated travellers reaching vulnerable communities. Audio

node.title: Major outage hits Amazon Web Services
node.description: The company said in a blog post Tuesday afternoon it did not have an estimated time for full recovery.

node.title: House readies for Tuesday vote on defense bill
node.description: The National Defense Authorization Act, or the NDAA, authorizes programs and sets spending guidelines for the Department of Defense and national security programs each year.

node.title: Biden's Supreme Court commission submits report on reforms
node.description: Mr. Biden's commission on the Supreme Court held six meetings, heard testimony from 44 witnesses and received more than 7,000 public comments.

node.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
node.description: Biden warns Putin on Ukraine.

node.title: Microsoft's new Surface Pro 8 targets hybrid work-home life
node.description: The device got its biggest upgrade since 2014, including new audio and video for streaming calls.

node.title: Coming to a grocery store near you: Low-carbon beef
node.description: Colin Beal grew up in a ranching family. Now he's working to curb the environmental damage caused by cattle.

node.title: Amid Push to Vaccinate Children, Other Challenges Deluge Pediatricians
node.description: At one clinic serving low-income children, treatment for health problems that have gone unchecked during the pandemic is more in demand than coronavirus shots.

node.title: Over 40 Percent of Foreigners in Hong Kong Considering Leaving Amid COVID Restrictions
node.description: Under China's COVID regulations, visitors are required to quarantine up to 21 days upon their arrival.

node.title: Angela Merkel Leaving German Chancellor's Office One Week Shy of Record for Longest Tenure
node.description: She will end her run a week short of the record held by her mentor, former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose tenure lasted from 1982 to 1998.

node.title: Europeans Push Companies to Allow Personal Repairs for Electronics to Cut Down on Waste
node.description: "We can't afford to live like we used to live, so we have to make a movement about not throwing things out when they're still working," one activist said.

node.title: Poland to Require COVID Vaccine to Hold Jobs in Medicine, Education and as First Responder
node.description: By March 1, a COVID vaccine will be required to work in health care, education or as a first responder in Poland, the country's Health Minister said Tuesday.

node.title: Could a Chewing Gum Reduce COVID-19 Spread? Researchers Believe It Can
node.description: "This gum offers an opportunity to neutralize the virus in the saliva, giving us a simple way to possibly cut down on a source of disease transmission," said a University of Pennsylvania researcher.

node.title: Jan 6 Committee Will Move Contempt Charges Forward if Mark Meadows Stops Cooperating
node.description: The committee said Wednesday's deposition will go forward as planned, and that if Meadows refuses to appear, the panel will refer him for criminal contempt.

node.title: Sexual violence support organisation says funding to work with children limited
node.description: A service helping children recover from sexual violence says there is little sign of extra help coming under a new national strategy.

node.title: Beijing Residents Want to See Americans 'Least' Amid Olympic Boycott: State Media Editor
node.description: China's Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Zhao Lijian, also criticized the diplomatic boycott saying that China will take "resolute countermeasures."

node.title: Robert E. Lee Statue Will Be Melted Down Into New Art for African American Heritage Center
node.description: The center emphasized in the proposal that no matter where the statue went, it would continue to be "an icon of violent white supremacy."

node.title: This angsty coming-of-age movie musical captures the full-bodied agony of being a teenager
node.description: The movie adaptation of the Tony Award-winning musical Dear Evan Hansen moves smoother on screen than on stage, thanks to deft direction and revisions to the Broadway script.

node.title: Top Aboriginal barrister Tony McAvoy SC expected to become NT Acting Treaty Commissioner
node.description: Australia's most senior Aboriginal barrister Tony McAvoy SC is expected to be appointed to the role of Northern Territory Acting Treaty Commissioner.

node.title: Why do modern missionaries travel overseas to evangelise, and what are the risks?
node.description: While 12 Christian missionaries are still being held almost two months after a brazen daylight kidnapping in Haiti, their community faces questions about the nature of their work: What are the risks of these trips and how do they prepare for the worst?

node.title: NSW Omicron infections grow, 'mystery' cluster traced to Nigeria
node.description: Health authorities in NSW have traced the source of mystery Omicron cluster in Sydney to Nigeria, as six new cases of the virus variant were recorded in the 24 hours to 8pm (local time) yesterday.

node.title: District health boards prepare for Covid-19 cases with mini-MIQs
node.description: Just two motel units have been set aside in Queenstown for people who might need help to isolate with Covid despite tens of thousands of Aucklanders about to hit town, mayor Jim Boult says.

node.title: President Biden’s pick for a key banking regulator backs out.
node.description: Saule Omarova withdrew herself from consideration to be comptroller of the currency after attacks from Republicans and banking lobbyists that labeled her a communist.

node.title: Redistricting Makes California a Top House Battlefield for 2022
node.description: As legislators across the country draw House maps to protect incumbents, a nonpartisan commission of California citizens is drafting one that will scramble political fortunes for both parties.

node.title: Player's mental health issues 'distress' NZ Rugby
node.description: New Zealand Rugby says comments by Black Ferns hooker Te Kura Ngata-Aerengamate that she had a mental breakdown during the side's recent Northern Hemisphere tour are distressing.
